quote: I always think a successful television series is the best job because it gives you community, it doesn't demand temporary insanity the way movies do, and you can be almost a normal person.
I basically think that I'm a fairly nice, normal person with just a few eccentricities.
I change, like every single normal person.
I work every day from 9:30 or so until lunchtime. In the afternoons, I become a normal person - go shopping and do the garden and look after my grandchildren.

Sometimes I forget that I am even watching myself, realizing that's me. It's like you almost become a fan yourself: You are just this normal person watching this show, and then you realize that it's your show. It's weird sometimes.
It's easy for me to stay grounded because I know I am just a girl, a mother, a daughter, a lover... a normal person who was lucky enough to do this job, and I know it's my job - not the person I am.
People follow me because I am just a normal person, and they can relate to me.
I'm a pretty normal person outside of the film world. It doesn't really affect me when I'm at school or with my mates.
When I'm at home, I want to be a normal person. I don't want to hear, 'Can I have your autograph?'

I'm beyond the normal person. I'm not your everyday Joe.

In certain parts of the world - where I'm at right now in New York, you're going to pay a whole lot more. In Los Angeles, your average starter home is a million dollars. So I need more money in Los Angeles to live like a normal person. If I live in another city, Iowa maybe, I wouldn't need as much.
I guess if you're a normal person and all of a sudden you're getting $10 million a year, it can go to your head.

Or 'ER,' to play a doctor - the things I'm actually good at. I mean, I'm pretty good on foreign policy - they won't even let me come read for that.

I read a lot, very passionately, from the time I was very young, but it was a constant battle; my mother would more or less let me be, but with my father, I was always searching for a place where he wouldn't find me. Whenever he saw me reading, he would tell me to put the book down and go outside, act like a normal person.
What surprises me is when people give me their mobile number. The other day, someone on a bus asked if I swear. I said I try not to, but of course I'm just a normal person.

I totally understand I'm an eccentric person; I'm not going to claim to be a normal person.

I often hear actors say during their interviews: 'I want to play a crazy person, a murderer, or someone who's on edge.' But that question scares me. I mean, of course there are characters I'd like to play, but I can't really say specifically who they are. It's much too hard to play a convincing normal person as it is.

I try to go to the gym three times a week. And I have to watch what I eat. I'm a normal person.

My dad can still do things like a normal person. He still cooks; he still watches my sister and my brother's baby when my mom's not home.
